issue.title: OpenSSL 1.0.2 build failure on Windows
issue.body: First error is that `oqs/oqs.h` can't be found while building `ssl3.h`.

comment.body:
Openssl build is getting error on mac:
=============
gcc  -Iinclude -pthread -m64 -fPIC -DNDEBUG  -MMD -MF fuzz/asn1.d.tmp -MT
fuzz/asn1.o -c -o fuzz/asn1.o fuzz/asn1.c
gcc  -Iinclude -pthread -m64 -fPIC -DNDEBUG  -MMD -MF
fuzz/test-corpus.d.tmp -MT fuzz/test-corpus.o -c -o fuzz/test-corpus.o
fuzz/test-corpus.c
engines/e_afalg.c:24:10: fatal error: 'linux/version.h' file not found
#include <linux/version.h>
         ^~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
==================

comment.body: I can't reproduce the error you experienced, @smashra: it builds fine for me on my Mac.

> @vsoftco why do you think this is a typo? The assumption is Module Learning with Rounding, MLWR seems like the right abbreviation. (In the NIST submission documentation, they use Module-LWR.)

My bad, sorry, I read it as "module learning with errors"... Please ignore.

issue.title: Re-enabled the Windows build
issue.body: The Windows build had been disabled after the removal of OQS as a submodule, and never was re-enabled on this branch. This PR makes it possible to build on Windows again, adding the instructions to the README.md and updating the build files.

comment.body: Yes, I tested on Windows; and I'll ask others to try the updated RC2 bits on Windows.

> Do what twice ?

It's what I wrote in my original comment: 

> Line 75 seems to imply that all platforms get `-Wl,--enable-new-dtags` in LD\_FLAGS, and then lines 76-78 seem to imply that Linux gets an additional copy of `-Wl,--enable-new-dtags` appended to LD\_FLAGS. 

Linux would get TWO copies of `-Wl,--enable-new-dtags` in LD\_FLAGS, all other platforms would get ONE copy of ``-Wl,--enable-new-dtags`` in LD\_FLAGS.

issue.title: Build issues on armv7l
issue.body:
### Environment
Platform: Raspberry Pi 3B
OS: Raspbian Stretch 9.4 armv7l
GCC 6.3.0 20170516 (Raspbian 6.3.0-18+rpi1+deb9u1)
GNU Make 4.1
autoconf/stable,now 2.69-10
automake/stable,now 1:1.15-6
git/stable,now 1:2.11.0-3+deb9u4
libssl-dev/stable,now 1.1.0f-3+deb9u2
libtool/stable,now 2.4.6-2
openssl/stable,now 1.1.0f-3+deb9u2
zlib1g-dev/stable,now 1:1.2.8.dfsg-5

### Steps to reproduce:
`git clone -b master --single-branch https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs.git`
`cd liboqs`
`autoreconf -i`
`./configure --prefix=<path-to-install-liboqs> --with-pic=yes`
`make`

### Issues
Using the instructions on the README, building on armv7l yields two main issues:

1.  AES and SSE2 gcc flags are included
`gcc: error: unrecognized command line option â€˜-maesâ€™; did you mean â€˜-mapcsâ€™?`
`gcc: error: unrecognized command line option â€˜-msse2â€™`
Almost all makefiles return this error when running make.


2. The architecture is not recognized (I think), giving unsupported architecture warnings when building. (Possibly causing also 1?).
`config.h:52:2: error: #error -- "Unsupported ARCHITECTURE"`
` #error-- "Unsupported ARCHITECTURE"`



### Quick fixes
- For 1:
Removing all AES and SSE2 flags on all Makefiles:
`for file in $(find . -name Makefile); do sed -i -e 's/-maes -msse2//g' $file; done`

- For 2:
Removing the `#else` clause in the preprocessor, in `src/kem/frodokem/config.h`:
`sed -i -z 's/#else\n#error-- "Unsupported ARCHITECTURE"//g' src/kem/frodokem/config.h`

Applying both quick fixes above results in a successful build. Have not tested further.

Am I missing some steps or forgetting to set environment variables to properly configure the build?

comment.body: Is that in scope for v0.1 or are we pushing this to a subsequent point release?

Fixed.

wrote:

> LD_FLAGS, and then lines 76-78 seem to imply that Linux gets an additional
> copy of -Wl,--enable-new-dtags appended to LD_FLAGS.
>
> Linux would get TWO copies of -Wl,--enable-new-dtags in LD_FLAGS, all
> other platforms would get ONE copy of -Wl,--enable-new-dtags in LD_FLAGS.
>
> â€”

issue.title: Build issues on armv7l
issue.body:
### Environment
Platform: Raspberry Pi 3B
OS: Raspbian Stretch 9.4 armv7l
GCC 6.3.0 20170516 (Raspbian 6.3.0-18+rpi1+deb9u1)
GNU Make 4.1
autoconf/stable,now 2.69-10
automake/stable,now 1:1.15-6
git/stable,now 1:2.11.0-3+deb9u4
libssl-dev/stable,now 1.1.0f-3+deb9u2
libtool/stable,now 2.4.6-2
openssl/stable,now 1.1.0f-3+deb9u2
zlib1g-dev/stable,now 1:1.2.8.dfsg-5

### Steps to reproduce:
`git clone -b master --single-branch https://github.com/open-quantum-safe/liboqs.git`
`cd liboqs`
`autoreconf -i`
`./configure --prefix=<path-to-install-liboqs> --with-pic=yes`
`make`

### Issues
Using the instructions on the README, building on armv7l yields two main issues:

1.  AES and SSE2 gcc flags are included
`gcc: error: unrecognized command line option â€˜-maesâ€™; did you mean â€˜-mapcsâ€™?`
`gcc: error: unrecognized command line option â€˜-msse2â€™`
Almost all makefiles return this error when running make.


2. The architecture is not recognized (I think), giving unsupported architecture warnings when building. (Possibly causing also 1?).
`config.h:52:2: error: #error -- "Unsupported ARCHITECTURE"`
` #error-- "Unsupported ARCHITECTURE"`



### Quick fixes
- For 1:
Removing all AES and SSE2 flags on all Makefiles:
`for file in $(find . -name Makefile); do sed -i -e 's/-maes -msse2//g' $file; done`

- For 2:
Removing the `#else` clause in the preprocessor, in `src/kem/frodokem/config.h`:
`sed -i -z 's/#else\n#error-- "Unsupported ARCHITECTURE"//g' src/kem/frodokem/config.h`

Applying both quick fixes above results in a successful build. Have not tested further.

Am I missing some steps or forgetting to set environment variables to properly configure the build?

comment.body: I was planning to push it to a subsequent point release. We'd have to both resolve the issue itself and figure out a continuous integration test that would exercise the build going forward, and the latter is what I don't know how to resolve at this point.

comment.body: Agreed; I'll spend a little bit of time tomorrow to see if we can build a minimal version of OQS that works on ARM (it used to); disabling some schemes might do the trick.
